Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Microgrid Cyber-Physical Testbed for Advanced Energy Management Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation project will acquire a microgrid cyber-physical testbed to enable the simulation, emulation, and testing of novel technologies being developed by South Dakota State University (SDSU) and its collaborators to enable microgrid development and deployment. The proposed microgrid cyber-physical testbed will be a resource available to all SDSU faculty, staff, postdoctoral researchers, graduate and undergraduate students, as well as other researchers across South Dakota and North Dakota. This cyber-physical testbed will enable the interdisciplinary development and collaboration among researchers in power electronics, power systems, controls, and energy markets, and laying the groundwork for collaborative research with industry as well as national and international partners. This project will not only advance energy sustainability, but also promote economic development and employment opportunities. Through the training of professionals in the use of this new system, this project will contribute to building a skilled workforce. The investigators will add new materials and lab curricula to current courses, and provide research and educational experiences to both graduate and undergraduate students. A workshop will be organized to train other students, faculty, and power professionals in the region, and help recruit underrepresented students to STEM programs.

Specifically, this equipment will enhance the research infrastructure of SDSU Microgrid Laboratory in three research areas: a) energy management and integration of renewable energy sources, b) cyber-physical system security, and c) energy resource design, simulation modeling, and power management. The research capacity will be further enhanced through collaborations with the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) by remotely connecting their Power-Hardware-In-The- Loop (PHIL) capabilities with the proposed cyber-physical testbed. This interconnection will leverage the SDSU Microgrid Laboratory's research capabilities and the extensive grid testing and high performance computing capabilities at NREL Energy Systems Integration Facility. The data collected during testing will provide new evidence of the interaction of new control architectures with the grid that includes different distributed energy resources. The installation of this unique equipment in the Dakotas will enable the design and testing of novel advanced energy management systems by analyzing the impact of integrating different energy resources in microgrids. The results are expected to advance energy infrastructure in remote areas, urban areas, and large buildings, with a focus on data centers. Furthermore, this equipment will enable real-time analysis on the impact of power management systems in storage device dynamics and lifetime, and enable the design of novel algorithms to dispatch batteries and ultra-capacitors, extending their lifetime and ensuring economical operation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The acquisition of a microgrid cyber-physical testbed enabled the simulation, emulation, and testing of novel technologies and controls being designed by South Dakota State University (SDSU) and collaborators. This equipment enhanced the research infrastructure of SDSU's Microgrid Laboratory in three research areas: a) energy management and integration of renewable energy sources, b) cyber-physical system security, and c) energy resource design, simulation and modeling, and power management. SDSU's research capacity was further strengthened through collaboration with the Sandia National Laboratories (Sandia) by collaborations involving  Power-Hardware-In-The-Loop (PHIL) testing with SDSU's cyber-physical testbed.

The microgrid cyber-physical testbed is a new resource available to all SDSU faculty, staff, postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduates as well as researchers across South Dakota and North Dakota. Initially, the equipment supported collaboration in research with University of North Dakota, Michigan Technological University, and University of Texas at El Paso and Sandia National Laboratories. The testbed directly supported testing, analysis, and emulation of novel technologies to enable microgrid development and deployment. The data collected during testing are used as new evidence on how the interaction of new control architectures with the grid, that includes different distributed energy resources, happens. Thus, the acquisition of this new equipment supports the design and testing of advanced energy management systems. In this project, three tasks were conducted: 1) survey and specification of the real-time PHIL system; 2) installation and integration of the system with current microgrid lab equipment; and 3) user training. The equipment was designed, purchased and installed in 2018. Since then, graduate and undergraduate students have been trained. In addition, an NSF INTERN supplement was provided to support one of the PhD students to have an internship at Sandia in order to strengthen the research collaborations among institutions.

Intellectual Merit: The acquisition of this unique equipment in the Dakotas region supports the design and testing of novel advanced energy management systems by analyzing the impact of integrating different energy resources in microgrids. As a result, major advances are expected to be developed to improve energy infrastructure in remote areas, urban areas, and for large buildings. Further, this equipment enable real-time analysis on the impact of energy management systems in storage device dynamics and lifetime. This equipment also enables the design of novel algorithms to dispatch batteries and ultracapacitors, extending their lifetime and ensuring economical operation. The data gathered during the experiments are analyzed and the results support the development of novel theoretical concepts to improve power quality and reliability of the electric grid.

Broader impact: This project helped to ensure a more efficient, reliable, and sustainable energy future and a lower-cost energy supply for the United States. The technology being developed in SDSU's Microgrid Laboratory will reduce power outages and grid disturbances, lower the peak demand of the electric power system, improve use and overall efficiency of distributed energy resources, and reduce costs and greenhouse gas emissions of energy systems. This project not only advances energy sustainability, but  also promotes economic development and employment opportunities, and increase the competitiveness of the region. Through the training of professionals in the use of this new system, this project  contributed to building a skilled workforce. The investigators added new material and lab curricula to current courses and provided research and educational experiences to 16 graduate and 9 undergraduate students.
